source.body: The culture medium should become totally dense or turbid the following morning.

source.description: Decant 6 x 1L TB medium into 6 x 2L autoclaved conical flasks.

To each flask add
of ampicillin per litre.

source.body: Prepare the stock antibiotics as 1000- fold to ensure consistent supplementation.

source.description:
After

When the temperature drops to

The following morning, decant the content of the 2 L conical flasks into 1 L Beckman centrifuge pots.
At the end of the run, carefully decant the supernatant back into the flasks.

source.body: The flasks can then be autoclaved and cleaned.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown

source.description:
Cleave PINK1 from His-sumo by dialysing the eluted protein against the dialysis buffer using the 3.5 kDa dialysis bag in the presence of His-Snep1 protease
in the cold room.

source.body: 1 mg of His-SENP1 per 25 mg of PINK1
The following day perform negative pull down to get rid of snep1 and sumo.

source.description: To remove His-sumo and His-senp1 from the cleaved protein, perform negative pull down.

To do this, still in the cold room, pack a
PolyPrep chromatography column with
nickel beads, equilibrate with binding buffer and gently by pipetting pass the dialysed protein mixture through the packed Ni-beads.

source.body: This traps the Histidine tagged proteins and your cleaved PINK1 protein passes through

source.description: Collect the flow through into a new falcon tube.

To concentrate the protein, consider using PEG20,000. To do this, the protein is dialysed against the PEG dialysis buffer. This takes between
to
depending on the starting volume

source.body: This is the tricky bit as the protein tends to aggregate/oligomerises and this make concentrating the protein using the vivaspin concentrator a bit difficult (increased agitation of the protein due to long concentration time).
Immerse the dialysis bag with protein in some peg2000 powder will equally do the magic in reducing the volume
The idea is that you want to reduce the volume drastically before moving to vivaspin concentrator to reduce the level of agitation on the protein.

source.description: Equilibrate the column with 2-column volume of the column size with the SEC buffer.

source.body: To obtain a crystallization grade protein, size exclusion chromatography is always the last purification step. This can be done on any of the Akta systems at on a superdex75 pg (26/600) or superdex200 pg 16/600 column
Before loading the sample clean the Akta sample loop with 2CV of the loop size first with water followed by the SEC buffer.

source.description:
Inject the sample and run the program (usually 1 ml/min flowrate and
fractions).

source.body: Using this program on superdex 75 column gives a chromatogram shown in Figure 1a.

source.description:
Run
of fractions within the peak (Figure 1a) on a 12% Tris Glycine SDS-polyacrylamide gel at the end of the run and stain with small amount Instant Blue.
After detaining a single band corresponding to ~ 48 kDa should be visible as shown in Figure 1b.

Pull together the cleanest fractions within the peak and concentrate using the vivaspin 30 kDa cut off to at least
or less this might take between
-
depending on your initial volume.

source.body: Here it is expected that you have less volume, however if your volume is large you might consider using the PEG method to reduce the volume before finishing off with vivaspin concentrator.

description: Mutations in PINK1 (protein kinase) and Parkin (ubiquitin E3 ligase) have been linked to familial early-onset Parkinson’s disease. PINK1 phosphorylates ubiquitin and the N-terminal ubiquitin-like domain (Ubl) of Parkin at a conserved Serine65 residue in both proteins to initiate mitophagy. Direct measurement of human PINK1 kinase activity has been challenging due to poor expression and low activity in vitro. The discovery of catalytically active insect PINK1 orthologues including Tribolium castaneum PINK1 (TcPINK1) and Pediculus humanus corporis PINK1 (PhcPINK1) has enabled elaboration of robust assays for measurement of PINK1 kinase activity (Woodroof et al., 2011). These assays can be employed for the study of human pathogenic PINK1 mutations and in vitro structural and functional studies of PINK1 (Kumar et al., 2017). Herein, we describe in detail a protocol for expression and purification of TcPINK1 for crystallisation as well as for in vitro characterisation.
